metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: Percentiles are used in statistics to give you a number that describes the value that a given percent of the values are lower than.
content.html: Percentiles are used in statistics to give you a number that describes the value that a given percent of the values are lower than.

content.text: If we take a look at the values of the wt (weight) variable from the mtcars data set:
content.html: If we take a look at the values of the wt (weight) variable from the mtcars data set:

content.text: What is the 75. percentile of the weight of the cars? The answer is 3.61 or 3 610 lbs, meaning that 75% or the cars weight 3 610 lbs or less:
content.html: What is the 75. percentile of the weight of the cars? The answer is 3.61 or 3 610 lbs, meaning that 75% or the cars weight 3 610 lbs or less:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
Data_Cars <- mtcars# c() specifies which percentile you want
  quantile(Data_Cars$wt, c(0.75))
# c() specifies which percentile you want

content.code:
Data_Cars <- mtcars# c() specifies which percentile you want
quantile(Data_Cars$wt, c(0.75))

syntax_highlighting.text:
Data_Cars <- mtcars# c() specifies which percentile you want
  quantile(Data_Cars$wt, c(0.75))
# c() specifies which percentile you want

content.code_html:
Data_Cars <- mtcars

# c() specifies which percentile you want
 quantile(Data_Cars$wt, c(0.75))

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
Data_Cars <- mtcars# c() specifies which percentile you want
  quantile(Data_Cars$wt, c(0.75))
# c() specifies which percentile you want

content.text: If you run the quantile() function without specifying the c() parameter, you will get the percentiles of 0, 25, 50, 75 and 100:
content.html: If you run the quantile() function without specifying the c() parameter, you will get the percentiles of 0, 25, 50, 75 and 100:

content.code_html:
Data_Cars <- mtcars

quantile(Data_Cars$wt)

content.text: Quartiles are data divided into four parts, when sorted in an ascending order:
content.html: Quartiles are data divided into four parts, when sorted in an ascending order:

content.text: Use the quantile() function to get the quartiles.
content.html: Use the quantile() function to get the quartiles.
